title: 107_hr2795
content: The Act may be cited as the "Agroterrorism Prevention Act of 2001" and addresses plant enterprise terrorism. The Act, known as the "Agroterrorism Prevention Act of 2001," focuses on amending Section 43 of title 18, United States Code, to include plant enterprise terrorism. The amendments expand the definition of "animal enterprise" to include plants and specify that it refers to commercial or academic entities using animals or plants for food or fiber production. The Agroterrorism Prevention Act of 2001 amends Section 43 of title 18, United States Code to include plant enterprise terrorism. The definition of "animal enterprise" is expanded to include plants, encompassing entities using animals or plants for food, fiber production, breeding, processing, research, testing, commercial retail, wholesale, distribution, exhibitions, educational or entertainment purposes, fairs, and facilities managed by food or fiber producers, processors, or researchers. The Agroterrorism Prevention Act of 2001 expands the definition of "animal enterprise" to include plants, covering entities involved in food, fiber production, breeding, processing, research, testing, retail, wholesale, distribution, exhibitions, education, entertainment, fairs, and facilities managed by food or fiber producers, processors, or researchers. The amendment addresses the loss of revenue directly related to the disruption of a plant or animal enterprise, including costs for business recovery and tuition expenses for students affected by property damage. The Agroterrorism Prevention Act of 2001 expands the definition of "animal enterprise" to include plants, covering entities involved in food, fiber production, breeding, processing, research, testing, retail, wholesale, distribution, exhibitions, education, entertainment, fairs, and facilities managed by food or fiber producers, processors, or researchers. The amendment addresses the loss of revenue directly related to the disruption of a plant or animal enterprise, including costs for business recovery and tuition expenses for students affected by property damage. The term "plant" is defined broadly to include any plant part used for propagation, genetic material, or biological materials modified for transgenic processes. (b) Clerical Amendment.--The table of sections in chapter 3 of title 18, United States Code, related to section 43 is amended. Enhancement of penalties for animal and plant enterprise terrorism under section 3. Section 43 of title 18, United States Code is amended to increase penalties for maliciously damaging or destroying property used by animal or plant enterprises with fire or explosives to a minimum of 5 years and a maximum of 20 years imprisonment, along with fines. Section 43 of title 18, United States Code is amended to increase penalties for damaging property used by animal or plant enterprises with fire or explosives to a minimum of 5 years and a maximum of 20 years imprisonment, along with fines. Additionally, the amendment includes provisions for economic damages resulting from violations of this section. SEC. 4. ANIMAL AND AGROTERRORISM CONSPIRACY PREVENTION. Amends Section 1961(1) of title 18, United States Code to include animal and plant enterprise terrorism. SEC. 5. NATIONAL AGROTERRORISM INCIDENT CLEARINGHOUSE. The Director will establish a national clearinghouse for information on crimes and terrorism related to animal, plant enterprises, commercial activities impacting the environment, and individuals connected to these activities. The clearinghouse will collect information from various law enforcement agencies. The national clearinghouse will collect and index information on crimes and terrorism related to animal, plant enterprises, and commercial activities impacting the environment. It will include details of incidents, suspects, and other relevant information to assist law enforcement agencies in investigations. The national clearinghouse will be user-friendly for law enforcement agencies, publicized by the Director, utilize resources from other government departments, accept assistance from private organizations, and coordinate with the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms. Definitions include "animal or plant enterprise" as per section 43 of title 18, United States Code. Authorization of Appropriations for fiscal years 2002 through 2007 as necessary for the Director of the FBI to carry out the national clearinghouse. SEC. 6. ANIMAL AND PLANT RESEARCH SECURITY PROGRAMS. The Director shall award grants to colleges and universities for security improvements and develop a security report on animal and plant enterprise terrorism threats. Eligibility for grants requires submission of an application by the college or university. Colleges and universities must submit an application to the Director of the National Science Foundation for grants related to security needs. Priority is given to institutions with the highest security needs. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2002 and 2003 for this purpose.
